app.security.title: Two-factor authentication feature
app.security.alert.title: For added security, we recommend configuring 2-Factor Authentication to help protect your account.
app.security.alert.des: Two-factor authentication (2FA) is a powerful security measure used to protect online accounts. Instead of just using one means of authentication such as a password, 2FA requires users to provide another authentication factor (OTP via email) or via Google Authorization to prove they are the owner of the account. This greatly increases the safety and security of your account, because someone else needs to have both to gain unauthorized access.

min.insync.replicas: Specify the minimum number of replicas of a partition that a producer needs to wait for acknowledgment from before considering the message to be safely written.
message.max.bytes: Specify the maximum size for a message sent to or from Kafka; it is a positive integer, measured in bytes.
log.retention.hours: Configure the retention time specification for partition logs in Kafka; this setting determines how long log data will be retained before being deleted.
log.segment.bytes: Configure the maximum size of each segment in a partition log; logs in Kafka are divided into segments for efficient data management and deletion.
auto.create.topics.enable: Configure whether to allow automatic creation of new topics when a producer sends a message to a topic that does not exist.
default.replication.factor: Configure the default number of replicas for a topic when the topic is created.
offsets.topic.replication.factor: Configure the default number of replicas for the '__consumer_offsets' topic; this topic stores information about the offset of consumers, helping to track the read position of each consumer in each partition.
log.retention.bytes: Configure the maximum size that a partition can use before old messages start to be deleted to maintain stable storage space, measured in bytes.
num.partitions: Configure the number of partitions that a topic can have when it is created. Each partition is a part of the topic and contains a portion of the data. Partitions help Kafka distribute and process data efficiently.
compression.type: Configure the type of data compression used when a producer sends messages to Kafka. Common values for compression.type include none, gzip, snappy, and lz4. Each value represents a different compression algorithm.
tooltip.kakfa.topic.max-message-bytes: The maximum size of one message
tooltip.kakfa.topic.min-insync-replicas: The number of in-sync replicas (including the leader) currently being synchronized
tooltip.kakfa.topic.unclean-leader: Enables or disables the ability to elect a leader when the leader broker loses connection with some replicas
tooltip.kakfa.topic.compression-type: Data compression method when pushing into the topic
tooltip.kakfa.topic.leader-replication: The list of replicas of the leader partition that the user wants to limit the replication speed from the leader to. Control or manage the replication speed for specific replicas
tooltip.kakfa.topic.message-downconversi: Parameter indicating whether the system allows automatic down-conversion of data when it is sent from the Producer with a higher protocol version down to a lower protocol version to meet the requirements from the Consumer
tooltip.kakfa.topic.delete-retention: The minimum time a message will be retained in a partition (in milliseconds) before being deleted
tooltip.kakfa.topic.segment-jitter: The parameter defining a random time interval added to the time of creating a new segment in the log. This random time interval helps prevent all partitions in the broker cluster from creating new segments at the same time, distributing the load and reducing the load on the broker
tooltip.kakfa.topic.flush: The minimum time interval between data pushes from the producer to the broker
tooltip.kakfa.topic.follower-replication: Specifies the list of replicas that the Kafka Broker limits the replication speed from the leader to
tooltip.kakfa.topic.segment-bytes: The maximum size for a segment of the log on the broker (in bytes)
tooltip.kakfa.topic.flush-messages: This setting allows specifying a time interval at which data will be forced to fsync to the log
tooltip.kakfa.topic.retention-ms: The minimum time a message will be retained in a partition (in milliseconds), a value of -1 indicates an unlimited time
tooltip.kakfa.topic.message-format: The Kafka protocol version used for the producer and consumer. Misconfiguring this parameter can lead to the Consumer using an old version that cannot use the data
tooltip.kakfa.topic.max-compaction-lag: The maximum time a message will not qualify to participate in the log compaction process. Only applies to logs that are being compacted. After compaction, the system retains only the latest value of messages with the same key
tooltip.kakfa.topic.file-delete: The delay time before deleting a file from the filesystem
tooltip.kakfa.topic.message-timestamp: Specifies how Kafka handles message timestamps
tooltip.kakfa.topic.min-compaction: The maximum time a message will not qualify to participate in the log compaction process. Only applies to logs that are being compacted. After compaction, the system retains only the latest value of messages with the same key
tooltip.kakfa.topic.preallocate: Determines whether the system should preallocate space for the segment before writing data
tooltip.kakfa.topic.min-cleanable: Determines the minimum ratio of dirty (uncompacted) data to clean (compacted) data that Kafka retains before performing compaction
tooltip.kakfa.topic.index-interval: The size of an entry in the index file of a segment (in bytes)
tooltip.kakfa.topic.retention-bytes: The maximum number of bytes a partition can retain before old data is deleted, a value of -1 indicates unlimited capacity
tooltip.kakfa.topic.segment-ms: The maximum time a segment of the log can exist before creating a new segment
tooltip.kakfa.topic.message-timestamp-di: The maximum time limit between the timestamps of producer messages and the timestamps of messages when written into the system
tooltip.kakfa.topic.segment-index: The maximum size for an index file of a segment (in bytes)
k8s-prem.intro: VNPT's advanced container service for Kubernetes (VAK) integrates storage, networking, load balancing, and security capabilities. VAK allows you to deploy applications in high-performance and scalable containers while providing full lifecycle management for enterprise-grade containerized applications.

mongodb.db.tooltip-1: Capped collections are fixed-size collections that insert and retrieve documents based on insertion order. Once a collection fills its allocated space, capped collections automatically remove the oldest documents in the collection without requiring scripts or explicit remove operations
mongodb.db.tooltip-2: Time series collection effectively stores series of measurements over a period of time. Time series data is any data collected over time and uniquely identified by one or more immutable parameters. The immutable parameters that define time series data are typically the metadata of the data source.
mongodb.db.name.validation-2: Database name must contain only letters, numbers, '_' and a maximum of 64 characters.
mongodb.db.collection.validation-2: Collection name must contain only letters, numbers, '_' and a maximum of 64 characters.
mongodb.db.size.validation-1: The maximum size of the collection is a positive integer and cannot be larger than 2147483648 B.
mongodb.db.size.validation-2: The maximum size of the collection cannot be blank.
mongodb.db.size.validation-3: The maximum size of the collection is a positive integer and less than 2097152 KB.
mongodb.db.size.validation-4: The maximum size of the collection is a positive integer and less than 2048 MB.
mongodb.db.size.validation-5: The maximum capacity of the collection is a positive integer and less than 2 GB.
mongodb.db.timefield.tooltip: The name of the field which contains the date in each time series document. Documents in a time series collection must have a valid BSON date as the value for the timeField
mongodb.db.metafield.tooltip: The name of the field which contains metadata in each time series document. The metadata in the specified field should be data that is used to label a unique series of documents. The metadata should rarely, if ever, change.
mongodb.db.granularity.tooltip: Possible values are seconds, minutes, and hours. The granularity should be set to a value that best matches the time between consecutive timestamps. This improves performance by optimizing the way MongoDB stores data in the time series collection.
mongodb.db.timefield.validation-1: timeField and metaField cannot be the same. Please enter a different name.

Storage Size does not decrease when a document is deleted or the document size shrink.

app.vlan.note16: DHCP is a dynamic IP address allocation mechanism for that subnet. That means when creating a Port without specifying any IP, DHCP will automatically assign an IP to the created Port. Advantages: No need to manage IP addresses, the system will automatically assign IP addresses. Disadvantages: DHCP will use 03 IPs for the DHCP server. This leads to the situation where if the subnet has only 8 IPs, for example, only 5 IPs will be available.
app.vlan.note17: Please select ranges within: '10.10.0.0 - 10.100.0.0, 172.16.0.0 - 172.31.0.0, and 192.168.0.0', and enter the correct address format: x.x.0.0/16, x.x.x.0/24

app.vlan.note31: If a subnet is added to a router interface, then the Gateway IP will not be disabled, and conversely, if a subnet does not have a gateway, then no router interface is added.
app.vlan.note32: DHCP is the mechanism for dynamically assigning IP addresses to the subnet. This means that when creating a Port without specifying an IP, DHCP will automatically assign an IP to the newly created Port. Advantages: No need to manage IP addresses manually, as the system will automatically allocate them. Disadvantages: DHCP will use three IPs for the DHCP server, which reduces the available IPs in the subnet. For example, if the subnet has only 8 IPs, only 5 will be available.
app.vlan.note34: If the user does not choose Disable GatewayIP, the system automatically takes the first address in the network range as the gateway, and the user cannot edit this gateway address.
app.vlan.note36: Enter a starting IP and an ending IP of the network range separated by a comma. Required to choose ranges within: '10.21.0.0 - 10.255.0.0', '172.16.0.0 - 172.24.0.0', and '192.168.0.0'. Enter the IP addresses in the correct format: x.x.0.0/16, x.x.x.0/24. The second IP should be greater than the first IP. For example: 172.16.0.2, 172.16.0.3.

app.ike.policy-create.name.tooltip: Ike Policy names include lowercase characters a-z, uppercase A-Z, numbers 0-9, hyphens (-) and underscores (_), can have spaces, minimum 1 character and maximum 50 characters.
app.ike.policy-create.Authorization.tool: The identity authentication algorithm for Ike Policy includes options: sha1, sha256, sha384, sha512 (based on bit-based cryptographic hash algorithm) default sha1.
app.ike.policy-create.Encryption.tooltip: The symmetric encryption algorithm used for Ike Policy includes the following options: 3des, aes-128, aes-192, aes-256 (based on the symmetric encryption algorithm with key length equivalent to the number of bits). define aes-128.
app.ike.policy-create.version.tooltip: Is a protocol used to establish secure communication between two devices over the internet. There are 2 options v1 and v2, v2 will include more authentication and encryption methods ensuring more security and data integrity. default is v1.
app.ike.policy-create.lifetime.tooltip: Ike Policy key lifetime measurement unit (default is seconds).
app.ike.policy-create.lifetime.value.too: Value of Lifetime units, Customers can optionally enter a value greater than 60 (default is 3600).
app.ike.policy-create.pfs.tooltip: Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) is a security feature that ensures that even if attackers gain access to encrypted communications, they cannot decrypt past communication sessions if they does not have access to the encryption keys used during those sessions. There are options group2, group5, group14 (default is group5).
app.ike.policy-create.Negotiation.toolti: There are 2 options: Main and aggressive (default is main which will ensure more security)
app.ike.policy-create.name.alert1: The IKE Policy name cannot be empty
app.ike.policy-create.name.alert2: The IKE Policy name only contains lowercase characters a-z, uppercase A-Z, numbers 0-9, hyphens (-) and underscores (_), can have spaces, minimum 1 character and maximum 50 characters
app.ipsec.policy-create.name.alert1: The IPsec Policy name cannot be empty
app.ipsec.policy-create.name.alert2: IPsec name, lowercase characters a-z, uppercase A-Z, numbers 0-9, dash (-) and underscore (_), can have spaces, minimum 1 character and maximum 50 characters on one's own.
app.ipsec.policy-create.Authorization.to: The identity authentication algorithm for IPsec Policy includes options: sha1, sha256, sha384, sha512 (based on bit-based cryptographic hash algorithm) default sha1.
app.ipsec.policy-create.Encryption.toolt: This protocol provides data confidentiality by encrypting packets. Includes tunnel and transport (default is tunnel).
app.ipsec.policy-create.Encryption.Al.to: The symmetric encryption algorithm used for IPsec Policy includes the following options: 3des, aes-128, aes-192, aes-256 (based on the symmetric encryption algorithm with key length equivalent to the number of bits). define aes-128.
app.ipsec.policy-create.Lifetime.tooltip: Unit of measurement for IPsec Policy key lifetime (default is seconds).
app.ipsec.policy-create.Lifetime.value.t: Value of Lifetime units, Customers can optionally enter a value greater than 60 (default is 3600).
app.ipsec.policy-create.pfs.tooltip: Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) is a security feature that ensures that even if attackers gain access to encrypted communications, they cannot decrypt past communication sessions if they does not have access to the encryption keys used during those sessions. There are options group2, group5, group14 (default is group5).
app.ipsec.policy-create.transform.toolti: IPsec's encrypted transport protocol includes options: esp, ah, ah-esp (default esp).
app.vpn.service-create.name.tooltip: Name of VPN Service, lowercase characters a-z, uppercase A-Z, numbers 0-9, dash (-) and underscore (_), can have spaces, minimum 1 character and maximum 50 characters.
app.vpn.service-create.router.tooltip: The router is created by default for the service.
app.vpn.service-create.name.alert1: VPN Service name cannot be empty
app.vpn.service-create.message.alert1: Router used for VPN, VPN gateway IP on VNPT Cloud side will be the gateway IP of the Router.
app.vpn.service-create.message.alert2: The Router is automatically created when a customer purchases a site-to-site VPN service and is dedicated to this service. Do not use the VPC default Router, which can conflict with transmission traffic when all packets transmitted over the internet pass through the same channel. 1 router
app.endpoint-create.name.tooltip: Endpoint name includes lowercase characters a-z, uppercase A-Z, numbers 0-9, dash (-) and underscore (_), can have spaces, minimum 1 character and maximum 50 characters.
app.endpoint-create.name.alert: Endpoint Group name cannot be empty
app.endpoint-create.type.tooltip: IPsec Connection requires Local Endpoints to be Subnet and peer endpoints to be CIDR.
app.endpoint-create.local.tooltip: Local Subnet(s). This field is valid and meaningful if Type is Subnet This is VLAN in VPC.
app.endpoint-create.add.router: Please check the Router and add Interface Router to use the service!
app.endpoint-create.cidr.tooltip: Remote peer subnet(s) with mask(s) in CIDR format separated by commas if needed (e.g. 20.1.0.0/24, 21.1.0.0/24) this field is valid if Type is CIDR. This is a list of remote subnets that need to be advertised via VPN Site to site.
app.endpoint-create.cidr.alert2: CIDR must be of the form x.x.x.0/24

app.vpn.connection-create.peerId.tooltip: Peer ID VPN Connection is the ID of the remote device making the connection. It can be formatted by IP address, domain name, email address or distinguished name. While establishing the connection, you need to ensure the correct format between the two VPN ends.
app.vpn.connection-create.peerId.alert2: Peer Id is not in the correct format
app.vpn.connection-create.remote.tooltip: The customer selects the created remote Endpoint Group.
app.vpn.connection-create.prekey.tooltip: Pre-Shared Key (PSK) String: The customer enters the shared key between the two tunnels to be able to decrypt the packet. The customer optionally enters this key.
app.vpn.connection-create.prekey.alert: Pre - Shared Key cannot be left blank
app.vpn.connection-create.maxtrans.toolt: Maximum Transmission Unit size for the connection: MTU is the maximum size of packet transmitted in the network.
app.vpn.connection-create.deadpeer.toolt: Dead peer detection actions: The timer for sending packets checks the status of both ends of the tunnel including the statuses: hold, clear, disable, restart, restart-by-peer.
app.vpn.connection-create.deadpeer.inter: Dead peer detection interval: Value of the time period in which the Dead peer detection timer will send test packets.
app.vpn.connection-create.deadpeer.timeo: Dead peer detection timeout: Status determination time is the timeout when no status response packet is received.
